post.title: Siloing of social groups makes for fertile ground for a 80-20 situation in online dating

div.p: You're onto something. However, I believe the problem is rooted in social dynamics that precede the online dating phenomenon.

Hypothesis: People learn from proximity. The ease of forming min-maxed cliques means that nerds get nerdier and the fuck-bois get fuckier. The lack of social attenuation leads to worse outcomes for both groups at large.
This mirror's my personal experience too. I have been incredibly fortunate in having experienced the whole spectrum of social group hierarchies.

ul.li: 'Scum of earth' bullying victim all through k-12 school.
Leader, public speaker, drama dude through university
Knows-everyone friendly nerdy guy through grad school

div.p: Throughout this time I was a virgin teetotaler for personal reasons. I hated pop, dancing and had an unreasonably high beauty standard and only male hobbies/ career choice. I still am fiercely anti-tribalistic and refuse to ever lie. Was approached frequently, but after a traumatic highschool wanted to work on myself first. Was also incredibly miserly when funded by parents, so never spent on ANYTHING. Go figure I'm a Late bloomer but am now in a relationship with a very attractive and intelligent woman, so don't mourn for me.
This has allowed me to be part of literally every group.

ol.li: The fuck-bois/ musicians (as the Designated driver)
mostly female groups / drama club (the harmless vocally single-by-choice guy).

div.p:
What blows my mind is how siloed these groups are. If you have have a certain hobby or lifestyle, then your access to certain other kinds of people is completely cut off.
I learnt an insane amount of what was considered 101 information from women friends and the popular kids a lot later in life than I would have thought. A majority of my nerdy-male friends only got that 101 information through me. Similarly, a lot of 101 information about men, introverts and nerds came as a total surprise to women and popular men.
The crazy part is that this isn't information that is protected. It is given away freely. But the complete lack of a casual & comfortable conversation across these groups siloes even this 101 tier info. The internet surprisingly doesn't do a great job of disseminating it either.
There are places it exists, but the signal to noise ratio to makes it really hard for an amateur to discern it. So, it is a sort of catch 22.

p.strong: The siloing of social groups makes for fertile ground for a 80-20 situation in online dating and the exact situation you describe. But, I think your observation is a symptom rather than the cause.

div.p:
Back in the day, you didn't choose your social circle. Neighbors, family, 2nd order networks and randomly assigned groups were far more important. Building one-dimensional groups was hard because filtering the network was hard. My hypothesis is this caused social networks to be far noisier and thus more diverse.
Transferring 101 info was far easier and the everyone knew the basics of interaction with the other group.

This mirrors my experiences too. I have ended up in far more socially diverse groups when the groups were randomly formed at first. eg: a foreign language class, a group of people who happened to land together and stuck together, my roomates who were assigned randomly in a mixed-gender international community home

p.strong: As long as the internet allows for more and more personality and gender homogenous groups to form. This problem will continue getting worse.
